Electric Field 
 
 An electric field is a field that surrounds a charged particle or object, and it exerts a force on any other charged particle within the field. The electric field is defined as the force per unit charge experienced by a charged particle. 
 
 Formula 
 The electric field strength (E) is calculated using the formula:

E = F/q

where F is the force experienced by a charged particle with charge q. 
 

Units 
 The unit of electric field strength is the volt per meter (V/m). 
 
 
 Sources : 
 
 Electric fields can be generated by a variety of sources, including:

>Stationary charges, such as in a static charge distribution
 >Moving charges, such as those in a current-carrying wire
 >Time-varying charges, such as those in an ac circuit
 >Effects
 >The effects of an electric field can be observed through 
 the movement of charged particles within the field, such as 
 the deflection of electrons in a cathode ray tube or the 
 movement of ions in an electrostatic precipitator. 
 
 Applications :
 
 Electric fields have numerous practical applications, including: 
 >Electrostatic levitation
 >Electrophoresis
 >Dielectrophoresis
 >Electric motors and generators
 >Electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection
 >Electrowinning in metallurgical processes.
